title: Tool Calling
text:
Recall: How do LLMs work?

Let‚Äôs revisit how LLMs work. This is important context for understanding why we need tools.


You write some words
The LLM writes some more words
You use those words


On their own, can LLMs‚Ä¶ access the internet? run code? send an email? interact with the world?

title: Tool Calling
text:
Let‚Äôs try it
library(ellmer)

chat <- chat("openai/gpt-4.1-nano")

chat$chat("Who are the keynote speakers at R/Pharma 2025?")

My training only includes data up until October 2023, and I do not 
have access to real-time updates or event-specific details beyond that. 

For the most accurate and current information about the keynote 
speakers, I recommend visiting the official R/Pharma 2025 
website or checking their latest event announcements.


Let‚Äôs try asking about things the model doesn‚Äôt know. This one fails - the model‚Äôs training data is old and it doesn‚Äôt have real-time event information.

title: Tool Calling
text:
Let‚Äôs try it

This one also fails - the model can‚Äôt access real-time weather data. No internet connection.

library(ellmer)

chat <- chat("openai/gpt-4.1-nano")

chat$chat("What's the weather like in Minneapolis?")

I'm unable to provide real-time weather updates.
For the most current weather in Minneapolis,
please check a reliable weather service or app like
Weather.com, AccuWeather, or your local weather provider.

title: Tool Calling
text:
Let‚Äôs try it

But this one‚Ä¶ the model actually gives an answer! It‚Äôs wrong (the date is from its training cutoff), but it shows the model will try to answer with what it knows.

library(ellmer)

chat <- chat("openai/gpt-4.1-nano")

chat$chat("What day is it?")

Today is October 27, 2023.

title: Tool Calling
text:
Tools

So how do we solve these problems? Tools! Also called functions or function calling.

a.k.a. functions, tool calling or function calling

Bring real-time or up-to-date information to the model
Let the model interact with the world


Tools are extra capabilities that you give to the LLM, like the ability to search the R/Pharma 2025 schedule or check the weather. These capabilities are things that the model can‚Äôt do on its own. The goal is to let the model pull in real-time or up-to-date information as needed.
They can also give the model new abilities to take action on behalf of the user.

title: Tool Calling
text:
The conversation starts with a user sending a message to the chatbot.
In this example, the user asks whether they can go to the pool today - which requires knowing the weather.
The model doesn‚Äôt have access to real-time weather data, just like we saw earlier with Minneapolis.

title: Tool Calling
text:
Now imagine we‚Äôve told the LLM that it has access to a tool called get_weather(). Knowing that it needs weather information and doesn‚Äôt have access to real-time data, the model decides to use the weather tool.
It sends back a message that includes a tool call - basically instructions to call the get_weather() function with the appropriate location argument. The model uses its training data to figure out the right location format (like a ZIP code).

title: Tool Calling
text: The programmer takes that tool call message and executes the actual function - in this case, querying a weather API with the location the model specified.

title: Tool Calling
text:
The weather API sends back some data:

The forecast is mostly sunny
High of 98¬∫F
Low of 78¬∫F

title: Tool Calling
text: The programmer sends that data back to the LLM. Note that it‚Äôs often in a pretty raw format, like JSON. Not the kind of thing you‚Äôd want to read directly unless you‚Äôre the kind of person who likes reading computer data formats.

title: Tool Calling
text: The LLM doesn‚Äôt mind JSON though, so it reads the data and generates a response that incorporates the data from the tool call.

title: Tool Calling
section: The LLM can‚Äôt run code by itself!
text:
The LLM can‚Äôt run code by itself!

This is crucial to understand - the LLM doesn‚Äôt execute tools. It just asks you to run them.

title: Tool Calling
text: The LLM also chooses the arguments for the tool. Here it picks the location based on the conversation.

title: Tool Calling
text: It uses its knowledge to fill in the right values - using information from its training data.

title: Tool Calling
text: The LLM can also call multiple tools in a single response if it needs to gather different information.

title: Tool Calling
text:
Demo: weather tool

But you‚Äôre programmers! You can automate this. Let me show you how to define tools that run automatically.

üë©‚Äçüíª _demos/19_tools/19_weather-tool.R

title: Tool Calling
Tool Calling
text:
Step 2: Define the tool

Here‚Äôs the pattern for defining tools in ellmer. You provide the function, a description, and argument types.

tool_get_weather <- tool(
  tool_fn,
  description = "How and when to use the tool",
  arguments = list(
    .... = type_string(),
    .... = type_integer(),
    .... = type_enum(
      c("choice1", "choice2"),
      required = FALSE
    )
  )
)

title: Tool Calling
text:
Step 2: Define the tool

Here‚Äôs the pattern for defining tools in ellmer. You provide the function, a description, and argument types.

tool_get_weather <- tool(
  get_weather,
  description = 
    "Gets the current weather for a specified zip code",
  arguments = list(
    zip_code = type_string("The zip code.", required = TRUE)
  )
)

title: Tool Calling
text:
Step 3: Register the tool
chat$register_tool(tool_get_weather)

title: Tool Calling
text:
Tools in Shiny

When using tools in Shiny apps, remember these key points - tools can interact with your app‚Äôs reactive state.


Define the tool function inside the server
You can update reactive values in the tool function!
You can read reactive values, if you isolate() reads. (Be careful!)

title: Tool Calling
text:
Learn more

These are the Posit packages for working with AI. We‚Äôve focused on ellmer and shinychat today, but there are others for different use cases.

title: Tool Calling
text:
Learn more
querychat: https://github.com/posit-dev/querychat

Chat with your data using natural language queries.

ggbot2: https://github.com/tidyverse/ggbot2

Talk out loud to create and iterate on plots.

Databot: https://positron.posit.co/databot.html

EDA assistant for Positron

Posit AI newsletter: https://posit.co/blog/?post_tag=ai-newsletter

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
First, let‚Äôs clarify two terms: a provider is a company that hosts and serves models. A model is a specific LLM with particular capabilities.



Provider

company that hosts and serves models

Model

a specific LLM with particular capabilities

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
How are models different?

Models differ across several dimensions. Let‚Äôs look at the main factors you‚Äôll consider when choosing a model.


Content: How many tokens can you give the model?
Speed: How many tokens per second?
Cost: How much does it cost to use the model?
Intelligence: How smart is the model?
Capabilities: Vision, reasoning, tools, etc.



Content: 200k tokens is normal, 1M tokens in some newer models
Speed: Gemini Flash hits ~350 tokens/sec, 100-200 is very fast, 50-100 normal. Speed is often a trade-off with intelligence.
Cost: $1-5 per million tokens is normal for big frontier models, < $1 for smaller, faster models
Intelligence is a stand-in for lots of concepts

title: Programming with LLMs
text: We‚Äôll start with Anthropic, a company that builds LLMs, in particular a family of models they call Claude.

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
Claude comes in different sizes, with different levels of intelligence.
They have a small model that‚Äôs fast and cheap, a large model that‚Äôs intelligent but expensive, and a just-right sized model that balances speed, cost, and intelligence.

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
In line with Anthropic‚Äôs branding, these models are named after different types of poetry.

Haiku is small, fast, and cheap
Sonnet is larger, more expensive, and more intelligent
Opus is the largest, most expensive, and most intelligent

Anthropic‚Äôs poetry naming offsets the fact that Anthropic has one of the most consistent naming schemes in the industry. (Yes, that‚Äôs says a lot.)

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
But there isn‚Äôt just one Claude model at different sizes. Anthropic keeps training new models which they generally release with a new version number.
Multiple versions are still active and available.

title: Programming with LLMs
text: When you‚Äôre choosing a model, you can get higher quality responses by moving up a size tier.

title: Programming with LLMs
text: And when new releases come out, you can often get similar quality improvements by moving up a version number. (This move tends to be cheaper than moving up a size tier.)

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
Oh, wait, sorry, to be very technically accurate, it turns out that the Opus models are only available for some Claude versions, but not all.
It remains to be seen if this will be an enduring pattern.

title: Programming with LLMs
text: All the major providers follow similar patterns - small/fast/cheap, medium/balanced, large/smart/expensive models.

title: Programming with LLMs
text: OpenAI has GPT models in different sizes, Google has Gemini in different sizes - same pattern everywhere.

title: Programming with LLMs
text: So when choosing a model, think about whether you need speed or intelligence, and pick the size that matches your needs.

title: Programming with LLMs
text: Here‚Äôs a comparison table if you want to see the specific numbers for different models. But don‚Äôt stress too much about this - pick something and try it.

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
How to choose a model
Generally: just start with a recent frontier model.

GPT-5
Claude Sonnet 4.5
Gemini 2.5 Pro


you‚Äôre probably not doing anything where you need to worry about cost effectiveness right away.

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
Now let‚Äôs see how to actually use different providers and models in ellmer. Ellmer supports all the major providers plus local models and enterprise options.






Providers

chat_openai()
chat_anthropic()
chat_google_gemini()



Local models

chat_ollama()



Enterprise

chat_aws_bedrock()




https://ellmer.tidyverse.org/

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
Chat in Easy Mode

Ellmer has a shortcut - the chat() function. Just pass a provider name and it picks a good default model for you.


library(ellmer)

chat <- chat("anthropic")

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
Chat in Easy Mode

See? It tells you which model it chose - Claude Sonnet 4.5.


library(ellmer)

chat <- chat("anthropic")
#> Using model = "claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929".

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
Chat in Easy Mode

Works the same way with OpenAI - it picks GPT-4.1 as the default.


library(ellmer)

chat <- chat("openai")
#> Using model = "gpt-4.1".

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
Chat in Easy Mode

Or if you want a specific model, use ‚Äúprovider/model-name‚Äù format.


library(ellmer)

chat <- chat("openai/gpt-4.1-nano")

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
Favorite models for today

These are the models I recommend using today. Nano and Haiku are fast, GPT-5 and Sonnet 4.5 are smarter. Pick based on what you‚Äôre doing.


OpenAI

gpt-4.1-nano
gpt-5

Anthropic

claude-sonnet-4-5-20250929
claude-3-5-haiku-20241022

title: Programming with LLMs
text: How to choose a model

title: Programming with LLMs
text: How to choose a model

title: Programming with LLMs
section: A picture is worth a thousand words
text:
A picture is worth a thousand words

Images get tokenized just like text. For LLMs, an image is roughly 170 tokens.


Or for an LLM, a picture is roughly 227 words, or 170 tokens.

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
üåÜ content_image_file

Use content_image_file() to pass an image from your local filesystem. Just provide the path to the image.


library(ellmer)

chat <- chat("openai/gpt-4.1-nano")
chat$chat(
  content_image_file("cats.jpg"),
  "What do you see in this image?"
)

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
üêà content_image_url

Or use content_image_url() to pass an image from a URL. Same pattern, different source.


library(ellmer)

chat <- chat("openai/gpt-4.1-nano")
chat$chat(
  content_image_url("https://placecats.com/bella/400/400"),
  "What do you see in this image?"
)

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
Your Turn 05_vision

Now try it yourself - use these food images to practice vision with LLMs. See what kind of descriptions they give.


I‚Äôve put some images of food in the data/recipes/images folder.
Your job: show the food to the LLM and ask it to write a corresponding recipe.


  
    ‚àí
    +
 
 05:00

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
üìë content_pdf_file / content_pdf_url

LLMs can also read PDFs. Use content_pdf_file() to pass a PDF from your filesystem.


library(ellmer)

chat <- chat("openai/gpt-4.1-nano")
chat$chat(
   content_pdf_file("prescribing-information.pdf"),
  "List the contraindications and serious adverse reactions."
)

title: Programming with LLMs
section: How would you extract name and age?
text:
How would you extract name and age?

Here‚Äôs a common problem - you have messy text data and need to extract specific fields like name and age.


age_free_text <- list(
    "I go by Alex. 42 years on this planet and counting.",
    "Pleased to meet you! I'm Jamal, age 27.",
    "They call me Li Wei. Nineteen years young.",
    "Fatima here. Just celebrated my 35th birthday last week.",
    "The name's Robert - 51 years old and proud of it.",
    "Kwame here - just hit the big 5-0 this year."
)

title: Programming with LLMs
section: If you wrote R code, it might look like this‚Ä¶

title: Programming with LLMs
section: If you wrote R code, it might look like this‚Ä¶
text:
If you wrote R code, it might look like this‚Ä¶

And here‚Äôs what running that code looks like. It works, but look at all the code you had to write!



dplyr::tibble(
  name = purrr::map_chr(age_free_text, extract_name),
  age = purrr::map_int(age_free_text, extract_age)
)

# A tibble: 6 √ó 2
  name     age
  <chr>  <int>
1 Alex      42
2 Jamal     NA
3 Li Wei    NA
4 Fatima    NA
5 Robert    51
6 Kwame      5



age_free_text

[[1]]
[1] "I go by Alex. 42 years on this planet and counting."

[[2]]
[1] "Pleased to meet you! I'm Jamal, age 27."

[[3]]
[1] "They call me Li Wei. Nineteen years young."

[[4]]
[1] "Fatima here. Just celebrated my 35th birthday last week."

[[5]]
[1] "The name's Robert - 51 years old and proud of it."

[[6]]
[1] "Kwame here - just hit the big 5-0 this year."

title: Programming with LLMs
section: But if you ask an LLM‚Ä¶
text:
But if you ask an LLM‚Ä¶

But with an LLM, you can just ask it to extract the name and age. Much simpler!

library(ellmer)

chat <- chat(
  "openai/gpt-5-nano",
  system_prompt = "Extract the name and age."
)

chat$chat(age_free_text[[1]])
#>

chat$chat(age_free_text[[2]])
#>

title: Programming with LLMs
section: But if you ask an LLM‚Ä¶
text:
But if you ask an LLM‚Ä¶

And it works! The LLM correctly extracts names and ages. But the output is still free text - wouldn‚Äôt it be nice to get proper R objects?

library(ellmer)

chat <- chat(
  "openai/gpt-5-nano",
  system_prompt = "Extract the name and age."
)

chat$chat(age_free_text[[1]])
#> Name: Alex; Age: 42

chat$chat(age_free_text[[2]])
#> Name: Jamal; Age: 27

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
Wouldn‚Äôt this be nice?

What we really want is a proper R list with named fields. That‚Äôs what structured output gives us.

chat$chat(age_free_text[[1]])
#> list(
#>   name = "Alex",
#>   age = 42
#> )

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
Structured chat output

Enter chat_structured() - this method returns structured data instead of text. But we need to tell it what structure we want.

chat$chat_structured(age_free_text[[1]])
#> list(
#>   name = "Alex",
#>   age = 42
#> )

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
Structured chat output

Define the structure with type_object() - specify each field and its type. Then pass it to chat_structured().

type_person <- type_object(
  name = type_string(),
  age = type_integer()
)

chat$chat_structured(age_free_text[[1]], type = type_person)
#> list(
#>   name = "Alex",
#>   age = 42
#> )

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
Structured chat output

And you get back proper R objects - a character vector for name, an integer for age. Ready to use in your analysis!

type_person <- type_object(
  name = type_string(),
  age = type_integer()
)

chat$chat_structured(age_free_text[[1]], type = type_person)
#> $name
#> [1] "Alex"
#>
#> $age
#> [1] 42

title: Programming with LLMs
text:
ellmer‚Äôs type functions

Here are all the type functions available in ellmer. You can also add descriptions to help the LLM understand what each field means.



type_person <- type_object(
  name = type_string("The person's name"),
  age = type_integer("The person's age in years")
)

title: Welcome and getting started

Outline

Welcome, introductions, workshop expectations (6 min)
Posit Cloud setup and verify API access (6 min)

title: Getting Started with LLM APIs in R
text:
LLMs are transforming how we write code, build tools, and analyze data, but getting started with directly working with LLM APIs can feel daunting. This workshop will introduce participants to programming with LLM APIs in R using ellmer, an open-source package that makes it easy to work with LLMs from R. We‚Äôll cover the basics of calling LLMs from R, as well as system prompt design, tool calling, and building basic chatbots.
No AI or machine learning background is required‚Äîjust basic R familiarity. Attendees will gain hands-on experience through guided exercises.

title: Getting Started with LLM APIs in R
text:
LLMs are transforming how we write code, build tools, and analyze data, but getting started with directly working with LLM APIs can feel daunting. This workshop will introduce participants to programming with LLM APIs in R using ellmer, an open-source package that makes it easy to work with LLMs from R. We‚Äôll cover the basics of calling LLMs from R, as well as system prompt design, tool calling, and building basic chatbots.
No AI or machine learning background is required‚Äîjust basic R familiarity. Attendees will gain hands-on experience through guided exercises.

title: Set up Posit Cloud
text:
Join the Posit Cloud workspace at https://bit.ly/llm-cloud.

I‚Äôve prepared a Posit Cloud workspace for workshop participants with a project for you to use during our time together. The project contains all of the files, API keys, and packages pre-installed and ready to go. All you need to do is log in and start coding!

If you don‚Äôt already have a Posit Cloud account, first sign up for a free account. You can create an account with your email or login with Google, GitHub or Clever.
Then, join the workspace on Posit Cloud: https://bit.ly/llm-cloud.
Once you‚Äôre part of the workspace, navigate to Content, then select the r-pharma-llm project to create and launch a new project just for you.

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
Outline
Anatomy of a conversation - HTTP requests, message roles, ellmer basics - Activity: 02_word-game (5 min) - Demo: 03_clearbot
Understanding statelessness - LLMs don‚Äôt remember - you send full conversation history each time
How LLMs work - Training on text data, tokens, probabilistic generation - Demo: 04_token-possibilities
Interactive chatting - Demo: 05_live - live_console() and live_browser()
How to think about LLMs - Think empirically, LLMs are jagged, embrace experimentation
Shinychat basics - Building apps with chat_mod_ui() and chat_mod_server() - Activity: 03_word-games (7 min)

LLMs and plots

Prompt engineering best practices

Three key questions: best models? clear system prompt? examples?
System prompt vs user prompt
Tips: use LLMs to write prompts, add structure, separate files, think out loud

Apply your skills

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
you‚Äôve probably talked with chatgpt or claude or gemini and seen a conversation that looks something like this:
You ask a question and ChatGPT responds. You can keep talking to ChatGPT and it keeps responding, and it feels kind of like you‚Äôre having a conversation with a person.
how is this happening? The entire conversation happens via HTTP requests and responses

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
What‚Äôs an HTTP request?

HTTP requests power the internet.
When you visit a website, your browser sends an HTTP request to the server hosting that website. The server responds to the request by sending back the HTML of the webpage. And then your browser makes a bunch more requests to get the images, stylesheets, and scripts that make up the page, etc.






google.comVery fast ServerGoogleHTTP/2 GET-> Host: google.comAre you feeling lucky?

title: Anatomy of a conversation
section: Talking with ChatGPT happens via HTTP
text:
Talking with ChatGPT happens via HTTP

Talking to an LLM like ChatGPT also happens via HTTP requests. When you send a message to ChatGPT, you‚Äôre sending an HTTP request to OpenAI‚Äôs servers, this time a POST request.
OpenAI processes the request, runs the model, gets the answer and sends it back to you as the response to that POST request.






Tell me a jokeVery fast ServerOpenAIHTTP/2 POST-> Host: api.openai.com-> /v1/chat/completions-> BODY: {‚Äútell me a joke‚Äù}knock, knock‚Ä¶

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
Messages have roles

Now let‚Äôs talk about how these messages are structured.
When you send a message to an LLM, you‚Äôre not just sending text - you‚Äôre sending text with a specific ROLE attached to it.
There are three main roles that messages can have, and understanding these roles is key to working with LLMs programmatically.

Then USER role - marks what the person using your app types
And ASSISTANT role - marks what the LLM responds with

This might seem like a small detail, but these roles are fundamental to how you control and guide LLM behavior.






Tell me a jokeUSERTell me anotherUSERknock, knock‚Ä¶ASSISTANTWhy did the data scientist‚Ä¶ASSISTANTYou‚Äôre a professional comedianand dad joke supplier‚Ä¶SYSTEM

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
Messages have roles

Now let‚Äôs talk about how these messages are structured.
When you send a message to an LLM, you‚Äôre not just sending text - you‚Äôre sending text with a specific ROLE attached to it.
There are three main roles that messages can have, and understanding these roles is key to working with LLMs programmatically.
[As the diagrams appear] - USER messages - what the person using your app types - And ASSISTANT messages - what the LLM responds with
This might seem like a small detail, but these roles are fundamental to how you control and guide LLM behavior.
there‚Äôs also the SYSTEM PROMPT - This is your instruction manual for the LLM. It‚Äôs where YOU as the developer tell the model how to behave, what personality to have, what constraints to follow. The user typically never sees this. think about how you would never really come across the chatgpt system prompt. The system prompt is particularly powerful because it persists across the entire conversation and shapes how the assistant responds to every user message.






Tell me a jokeUSERTell me anotherUSERknock, knock‚Ä¶ASSISTANTWhy did the data scientist‚Ä¶ASSISTANTYou‚Äôre a professional comedianand dad joke supplier‚Ä¶SYSTEM

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
Message roles

to recap








Role
Description




system_prompt
Instructions from the developer (that‚Äôs you!)to set the behavior of the assistant


user
Messages from the person interactingwith the assistant


assistant
The AI model‚Äôs responses to the user

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
So now that we understand how messages work and what roles they play, let‚Äôs see how to actually DO this in R.
ellmer is an open source R package from Posit that makes it easy to work with LLMs. It handles all the HTTP requests and API details for you, so you can focus on building with LLMs rather than wrestling with API documentation.
Let‚Äôs see what the code looks like.

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
First step - load the ellmer package, just like any other R package.


library(ellmer)

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
Now we create a chat object. This sets up a connection to OpenAI‚Äôs API. The chat object is what we‚Äôll use to send messages and get responses.


library(ellmer)

chat <- chat_openai()

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
Now we can use the chat object to send a message using the chat method
and pass in our message as a string.


library(ellmer)

chat <- chat_openai()

chat$chat("Tell me a quick fact about sheep.")

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
And we get a response back!
think back to what we just learned about roles. What are the user and assistant roles in this example?
The user role is our question - ‚ÄúTell me a quick fact about sheep‚Äù The assistant role is the response we got back.


library(ellmer)

chat <- chat_openai()

chat$chat("Tell me a quick fact about sheep.")
#> Sheep have excellent memories‚Äîthey can remember up
#> to 50 individual sheep faces and even recognize
#> human faces for years!


‚ùì What are the user and assistant roles in this example?

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
One of the nice things about ellmer is that you can easily inspect the chat object to see the full conversation history.
If we just call ‚Äòchat‚Äô, we can see all the messages and their roles. You can see the user message and the assistant response, as well as how many tokens were used
but what about the third role ‚Äì the system prompt? where is that? we didn‚Äôt set up one, so the model just uses whatever behavior it defaults to


chat
<Chat OpenAI/gpt-4.1 turns=2 tokens=15/23 $0.00>
‚îÄ‚îÄ user [15] ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
tell me a quick fact about sheep
‚îÄ‚îÄ assistant [23] ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
Sheep have excellent memories‚Äîthey can remember up to 50 individual sheep faces and even recognize human faces for years!


‚ùì What about the system prompt?

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
the chat_openai() function includes a system_prompt argument where you can set a system prompt Let‚Äôs try adding one
This is a silly example - we‚Äôre telling the model to always answer in haikus. But it demonstrates how system prompts work and can control model behavior


library(ellmer)

chat <- chat_openai(
  system_prompt = "Always answer in haikus."
)

chat$chat("What is chirality?")

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
It actually answered in a haiku.
The system prompt shapes EVERY response the model gives. this is really powerful because you can exert quite a bit of control over how the model behaves


library(ellmer)

chat <- chat_openai(
  system_prompt = "Always answer in haikus."
)

chat$chat("What is chirality?")

Left and right differ‚Äî
mirrored, yet not the same thing.
Chirality's twist.

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
Now when we inspect the chat object, we can see all three roles - system, user, and assistant. The system prompt is there shaping the conversation.


 ellmer
chat

<Chat OpenAI/gpt-4.1 turns=3 tokens=22/22 $0.00>
‚îÄ‚îÄ system [0] ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
Always answer in haikus.
‚îÄ‚îÄ user [22] ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
What is chirality?
‚îÄ‚îÄ assistant [22] ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ
Left and right differ‚Äî  
mirrored, yet not the same thing.  
Chirality's twist.

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
You just saw in clearbot what‚Äôs really happening when you have a conversation with an LLM.
Those conversations look something like this - you ask, it responds, back and forth. But as clearbot showed, something interesting is happening behind the scenes.

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
Is this actually a conversation?

It IS a conversation, but it works differently than you might think.

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
LLMs are stateless

The LLM doesn‚Äôt remember anything between requests
You have to send the entire conversation history with every message
The LLM reconstructs the ‚Äúconversation‚Äù from what you send


The LLM has amnesia - it forgets everything after each response. Each API request is completely independent.
Just like if you were talking to someone with amnesia, you have to recap the entire conversation every time you want to continue. That‚Äôs what clearbot showed you - the full history being sent with each request.
This isn‚Äôt a limitation of transformers specifically - it‚Äôs how the HTTP API is designed. Though it aligns with how transformers work (each forward pass is independent).

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
How do LLMs understand?

This is how LLMs understand the conversation. They‚Äôre trained on massive amounts of text data - essentially everything written on the internet, in books, etc. By learning patterns from all this text, they develop the ability to understand context, meaning, and how language works.



If you read everythingever written‚Ä¶

Books and stories
Websites and articles
Poems and jokes
Questions and answers


‚Ä¶then you could‚Ä¶

Answer questions
Write stories
Tell jokes
Explain things
Translate into any language

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
How do LLMs respond?

Now let‚Äôs talk about how LLMs construct their responses. They don‚Äôt generate whole sentences at once - they generate responses token by token, choosing the most likely next piece based on everything they‚Äôve seen so far.

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
Tokens

LLMs don‚Äôt think in words - they think in tokens. This is the fundamental unit they use to construct responses, one token at a time.


Fundamental units of information for LLMs
Words, parts of words, or individual characters

‚Äúhello‚Äù ‚Üí 1 token
‚Äúunconventional‚Äù ‚Üí 3 tokens: un|con|ventional

Important for:

Model input/output limits
API pricing is usually by token

Not just words, but images can be tokenized too

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
Think Empirically, Not Theoretically

It‚Äôs okay to (mostly) treat LLMs as black boxes.
Just try it! When wondering if an LLM can do something,
experiment rather than theorize
You might think they could not possibly do things
that they clearly can do today
And you might think surely they can do something
that it turns out they‚Äôre terrible at



Understanding the technical details can lead to bad intuition about capabilities
You might think ‚Äúthey could not possibly do things that they clearly can do today‚Äù
Empirical testing reveals actual capabilities vs.¬†theoretical limitations

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
LLMs are jagged

Don‚Äôt expect smooth, predictable performance across tasks. LLMs can surprise you - excelling at some complex tasks while struggling with seemingly simple ones.

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text: LLMs are jagged

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
Embrace the Experimental Process

Explore!
Focus on learning and engaging with the technology, not outcomes
Failure is valuable!
those are some of the most interesting conversations that we have
It doesn‚Äôt have to be a success.
Attempts that don‚Äôt work still provide insights



Use the best models available for experimentation
Don‚Äôt constrain yourself to ‚Äúpractical‚Äù applications initially
Think of it as forming your own independent conclusions about usefulness

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text: Start Simple, Build Understanding

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
Start Simple, Build Understanding

We‚Äôre going to focus on the core building blocks.
All the incredible things you see AI do
decompose to just a few key ingredients.
Our goal is to have fun and build intuition
through hands-on experience.



Think very generally about what tools can do - they‚Äôre as powerful as any software you can write
Remember: ‚ÄúEverything decomposes‚Äù to the basic components once you understand the underlying APIs
Build intuition through hands-on experience rather than theoretical study
We want to have fun in this course! It‚Äôs worth saying up front that our examples are not necessarily practical, but they‚Äôre full of practical lessons.

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
Console
Browser





live_console(chat)
live_browser(chat)





As we‚Äôll see, everything we‚Äôre going to do today can be done in either R or Python and ellmer and chatlas are designed to be similar.
But they‚Äôre in different languages and those languages have different conventions and idioms, so they‚Äôre not completely identical. If they were, one or the other would start to feel unnatural to use.

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text: shinychat and ellmer work together - ellmer handles the LLM API calls, shinychat provides the chat interface for Shiny apps.

title: Anatomy of a conversation
Anatomy of a conversation
Anatomy of a conversation
text:
shinychat in R

Use the shinychat module pattern - chat_mod_ui in the UI and chat_mod_server in the server. The ‚Äúchat‚Äù ID connects them.

Use the shinychat chat module
library(shiny)
library(bslib)
library(shinychat)
library(ellmer)

ui <- page_fillable(
  chat_mod_ui("chat")
)

server <- function(input, output, session) {
  chat_mod_server("chat")
}

shinyApp(ui, server)

title: Anatomy of a conversation
text:
shinychat in R

Finally, create the chat client and pass it to chat_mod_server. Now you have a working chatbot in your Shiny app!

Create and hook up a chat client to use in the app
library(shiny)
library(bslib)
library(shinychat)
library(ellmer)


ui <- page_fillable(
  chat_mod_ui("chat")
)

server <- function(input, output, session) {
  client <- chat_openai()
  chat_mod_server("chat", client)
}

shinyApp(ui, server)

title: Prompt Engineering
text:
Reminder: the system_prompt arg
prompt <- 
   "Your primary goal is to accurately and thoroughly 
   understand patterns in data."

chat <- chat("anthropic", system_prompt = prompt)

title: Prompt Engineering
text:
Reminder: the system_prompt arg
chat <- 
   chat(
      "anthropic", 
      system_prompt = readr::read_file("prompt.md")
   )

title: Prompt Engineering
text:
Three questions to ask yourself

Did you use the best models?
Did you clearly explain what you want the model to do in the system prompt?
Did you provide examples of what you want?



There‚Äôs going to be 3 questions we‚Äôre usually going to ask you in this order? Number one, did you try the best models? Did you try this with at least like Claude Sonnet 4.5, or GPT 4.1?
so number one like, did you use the best models number 2 is, did you ask for what you wanted in the system prompt like. Did you describe the behavior that you were looking for from the model in the system prompt?
And then number 3, if you did do that. Did you provide an example of what you wanted? And usually that, that, you know, takes care of a lot of the the kind of misbehaving that people see.

title: Prompt Engineering
text:
System prompt vs.¬†user prompt

A common question - what goes in the system prompt versus the user prompt? Here‚Äôs the simple rule.

Short answer: put instructions and background knowledge in the system prompt.

title: Prompt Engineering
text:
More tips

Here are more practical tips. First - use LLMs to write your prompts! Claude has a prompt generator that‚Äôs excellent for this.

Use LLMs to help draft or improve your prompts.
E.g., this input to Claude‚Äôs prompt generator:

Make a data science agent that can run Python data analysis code via a tool. Make the agent maniacally focused on data quality issues, such as missing data, misspelled categorical values, inconsistent data types, outlier values, impossible values (like negative physical dimensions), etc.

Generates this prompt:
You are a data science agent with an obsessive focus on data quality. You have been given access to a dataset and a Python code execution tool. Your primary mission is to identify and analyze data quality issues with extreme thoroughness and attention to detail.

Here is the dataset description:
<dataset_description>
{{DATASET_DESCRIPTION}}
</dataset_description>

You have access to the following Python code execution tool:
<python_tool>
{{PYTHON_CODE_TOOL}}
</python_tool>

Your role is to act as a maniacally thorough data quality inspector. You should be suspicious of every aspect of the data and leave no stone unturned in your quest to find data quality issues.

Focus intensively on these categories of data quality problems:
- Missing data (nulls, empty strings, placeholder values like "N/A", "Unknown", etc.)
- Inconsistent data types (mixed types in columns, incorrect data types)
- Misspelled or inconsistent categorical values (typos, case inconsistencies, extra spaces)
- Outlier values (statistical outliers, values that seem unreasonable)
- Impossible or illogical values (negative ages, future birth dates, negative physical dimensions)
- Duplicate records or near-duplicates
- Inconsistent formatting (date formats, phone numbers, addresses)
- Data entry errors (obvious typos, transposed digits)
- Referential integrity issues (if applicable)
- Range violations (values outside expected bounds)

Your analysis process should be systematic and comprehensive:

1. Start by loading and examining the basic structure of the dataset
2. Check data types and identify any type inconsistencies
3. Examine missing data patterns thoroughly
4. Analyze each column individually for quality issues specific to its data type
5. Look for statistical outliers and impossible values
6. Check for duplicates and near-duplicates
7. Examine categorical variables for inconsistencies
8. Validate logical relationships between columns
9. Look for formatting inconsistencies

Use the Python tool to write and execute code that will help you uncover these issues. Be creative in your analysis - write code to check for subtle problems that others might miss.

Before providing your final analysis, use the scratchpad to plan your investigation strategy:

<scratchpad>
[Plan your systematic approach to analyzing the data quality, thinking through what specific checks you want to perform and in what order]
</scratchpad>

Then execute your analysis using the Python tool. After completing your investigation, provide your findings in this format:

<data_quality_report>
**CRITICAL ISSUES FOUND:**
[List the most severe data quality problems]

**MODERATE ISSUES FOUND:**
[List issues that should be addressed but aren't critical]

**MINOR ISSUES FOUND:**
[List smaller issues that could be improved]

**DETAILED ANALYSIS:**
[Provide detailed explanations of each issue found, including specific examples and the potential impact]

**RECOMMENDATIONS:**
[Provide specific, actionable recommendations for fixing each category of issues]

**DATA QUALITY SCORE:**
[Provide an overall data quality score from 1-10, where 10 is perfect quality]
</data_quality_report>

Remember: Be obsessively thorough. Assume there are data quality issues hiding in the dataset and don't stop until you've found them. Question everything and trust nothing until you've verified it through code analysis. Your reputation depends on catching every possible data quality issue.

title: Prompt Engineering
Prompt Engineering
text:
More tips

When prompts get long, move them to separate files. This makes your code cleaner and version control easier to read.

Get large prompts out of the code and into separate files.

Easier to read (both locally and on GitHub)
Easier to read diffs in version control

title: Prompt Engineering
text:
More tips

Advanced technique - make the model think out loud. This helps it follow complex rules or constraints.

Force the model to say things out loud.
E.g., ‚ÄúUse no more than three rounds of tool calls‚Äù => ‚ÄúBefore answering, note how many tool calls you have made inside  tags. If you have made three, stop and answer.‚Äù

title: Prompt Engineering
text:
More tips

Finally, all the major providers have excellent documentation on prompt engineering. These are great resources to dive deeper.

See Anthropic‚Äôs Prompt Engineering Overview and OpenAI‚Äôs OpenAI Cookbook are excellent, and contain lots of tips and examples.
Google‚Äôs Prompt Design Strategies may also be useful.
